titleStmt.title: The Face of Getting Over: Facial Formidability Informs Expectations for the Performance of Male Professional Wrestlers

analytic.title: The Face of Getting Over: Facial Formidability Informs Expectations for the Performance of Male Professional Wrestlers

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: The simulated nature of professional wrestling requires promoters to identify performers who appear capable of winning legitimate fights. This appearance may track ancestrally relevant morphological features from which perceivers accurately infer men's formidability. One feature through which perceivers infer men's formidability is their facial width-to-height ratio (fWHR), which is diagnostic of men's actual fighting ability and connotes heightened aggression. This study considered how fWHR informs how professional wrestling fans evaluate the effectiveness of men in their performance. Participants evaluated the extent to which men appeared effective at utilizing various performance styles and how likely they would be to promote these men to the top positions in a company. High-fWHR men appeared most effective as brawlers and powerhouses but less effective in more technical performances compared to low-fWHR men. Formidability additionally tracked an interest in positioning men to be stars of a company. These results indicate how functional formidability inferences inform modern decision-making in simulated combat based on expectations of physical prowess.

div.head: WRESTLING AND FACES 3 Public Significance Statement
div.p: Professional wrestling fans assessed a variety of men's faces in terms of whether such men appeared effective in various types of professional wrestling performances. These men varied in their relative facial width-to-height ratio (fWHR), a facial structure connoting men's physical prowess that appears threatening to perceivers. Men with relatively high fWHRs appeared more effective while performing as brawlers or using their strength, whereas relatively low fWHRs connoted greater effectiveness in technical acumen. These results suggest that evolved perceptual systems to identify threats may inform modern performances of simulated combat.

div.head: WRESTLING AND FACES 4
div.p: Professional wrestling reflects an understanding of physical conflict throughout human evolutionary history. The simulated combat resonates with lay perceivers' expectations of formidable opponents. From an affordance management perspective (Neuberg et al., 2020), these expectations could reflect an understanding of physical features predictive of success in combat.
Humans evolved perceptual systems to facilitate identification of conspecifics able to inflict physical harm based on static and dynamic features (e.g., Neuberg et al., 2011;Sell et al., 2009).
The accompanying evolutionary history of choosing allies to solve survival goals could direct perceivers to identify formidable men for combat (Lukaszewski et al., 2016;Salmon, 2016).

Wrestling promoters could recognize this acuity toward formidable physical features and this ancestral logic. This could lead to decide whom to promote based on their believability to win physical fights (Snowden, 2012).
Perceivers use facial structures to estimate men's abilities in combat. One feature that has been fairly robust in informing coalitional decisions is facial width-to-height ratio (fWHR).

Various components of this ratio are diagnostic of men's testosteronization and thus physical prowess (e.g., Hodges-Simeon et al., 2021;Whitehouse et al., 2015). From this testosteronization is a more aggressive interpersonal style among high-fWHR men that fosters a masculinized facial structure. People perceive high-fWHR men as prone to aggression, with perceptions corresponding with actual aggressive behavior (Durkee & Ayers, 2021;Geniole & McCormick, 2013;Haselhuhn et al., 2015). Heuristic associations between aggression and this physical feature inform expectations of men's combat prowess. People expect high-fWHR men to be capable of achieving group goals more effectively through aggressive means (Brown et al., 2022a). It could thus be possible that expectations of men's physical prowess, as gleaned from fWHR, could shape a professional wrestling audience's expectation for a given performer. This WRESTLING AND FACES 5 study sought to identify how formidability informs perceptions of professional wrestlers.

div.head: Formidability Inferences and Social Affordances
div.p: Men's formidability is highly salient to perceivers. Recognition of this formidability is multimodal (e.g., Aung et al., 2021), automatic (Durkee et al., 2018), and tracked through cues to men's upper body strength (Frederick & Haselton, 2007;Lukaszewski et al., 2016;Sell et al., 2017). Facial structures additionally covary with the testosteronization implicated in men's strength (Holzleitner & Perrett, 2016;Price et al., 2017). Androgen exposure throughout male's prenatal and adolescent development facilitates this masculinization, increasing muscle mass and facial width (Whitehouse et al., 2015). The immediacy of face-to-face interactions in human evolutionary history could have led perceivers to use facial structures as functional cues to their physical capabilities and aggressive intentions (Sell et al., 2009).

Men's fWHR informs perceptions of formidability. Several components of this ratio are diagnostic of masculinization (Hodges-Simeon et al., 2021;Summersby et al., 2022), which contribute to a connotation of formidability to perceivers . The recurrence of physical conflict in men's evolutionary history would have led selection to favor masculinized men (Puts, 2010). Male mixed martial arts fighters have more favorable win-loss records when they have these features (Třebický et al., 2015;Zilioli et al., 2015;cf. Caton et al., 2022). High-fWHR men are also proficient grapplers (Caton et al., in press).

Acuity toward high-fWHR men could have evolved selection pressures to identify coalitional benefits afforded along with the imposed costs. Functional heuristics could have emerged to ensure perceivers could estimate costs and benefits. High-fWHR men appear mentally rugged (Brown et al., 2021;2022a;Hehman et al., 2015). Nonetheless, such features implicate men as antagonistic and have a kernel of truth (Brown et al., 2022b, 2022c, Durkee & WRESTLING AND FACES 6 Ayers, 2021Haselhuhn et al., 2013). Competing inferences could inform expectations in professional wrestling based on heuristics of combat (e.g., Pham et al., 2017;Sell et al., 2022).

div.head: Translation of Coalitional Value into Professional Wrestling
div.p: Implicit rules of combat shaped implicit theories of successful combatants. Formidable men receive more social esteem (Apicella, 2014;Lukaszewski et al., 2016;von Rueden & Van Vugt, 2015), likely based on their advantages in competitions, including wrestling (Caton et al., in press). As professional wrestling evolved from legitimate catch wrestling contests to scripted displays in the Early 20 th Century, promoters could have used this understanding in booking shows to draw audiences based on who appeared to be more competent as a wrestler. 1 This booking could be rooted in that effective displays of simulated combat would benefit from acknowledging humans' evolved psychological calculus to address physical features germane to interpersonal decisions related to survival (Salmon, 2016(Salmon, , 2018. Simulations of actual combat are common cross-culturally, which have been argued to provide information to coalitions about potential opponents' formidability (Sugiyama et al., 2021). A consequence of simulated combat is covariance with an evolved acuity to men's formidability, which affords individuals the opportunity to identify coalitional allies and damaging rivals (Sell et al., 2009). This understanding could similarly manifest as the promotion of men who appear supernormal in their formidability (e.g., Hulk Hogan; see Burch & Johnsen, 2020).

Formidability inferences could lead promoters to place formidable men atop their cards to sell the illusion of legitimate contests. Historically, promoters booked legitimately good wrestlers as champions (e.g., Danny Hodge, Antonio Inoki, Brock Lesnar). A consensus often emerged to book champions who appeared mature, which corresponds with research suggesting that inferences of formidability covary with those of maturity (Sacco & Hugenberg, 2009). These WRESTLING AND FACES 7 heuristics helped maintain the illusion of legitimacy with the added benefit of their ability to win actual fights if the challenger reneged from the script (Snowden, 2012). For example, Lou Thesz won legitimate fights as NWA Worlds Heavyweight Champion. In 1964, Kintaro Ohki tried to score a legitimate pin on Thesz, only to have Thesz retaliate and actually win (Lutzke, 2014). In addition to this realism, terminology emerged to describe a wrestler's ability to suspend the crowd's disbelief. Within modern contexts, wrestlers demonstrating exemplary technique appear to have objectively better matches that create an illusion of realism (Platt & Horton, 2020).

div.head: Ancestrally Informed Dramaturgy
div.p: As professional wrestling diversified in its presentation based on a growing number of cross-cultural influences, different types of performers ascended the industry's hierarchy as top stars. This diversification would have led to performers without ancestrally relevant appearances to have top billing despite still being capable of suspending the disbelief of the audience (e.g., Rey Mysterio, Johnny Gargano). The advent of these performers has seen the emergence of folk language designations of different "styles" similar to personality traits (e.g., Mehl et al., 2006).

For example, formidable men's upper body strength would implicate them as likely to employ a "powerhouse" wrestling style, whereas physically smaller men could be regarded as requiring more technique. This ascription of technical acumen to physically smaller men would track previous research demonstrating perceptions of high-fWHR men as having less mental complexity (Brown et al., 2021;. Wrestling promoters could have recognized these heuristic judgments about men and booked storylines accordingly. Table 1 has examples of commonly described professional wrestling styles.

The increasingly dramaturgical nature of wrestling is further shaped by the inclusion of specific characters that verbalize their intentions their intentions through promos (i.e., WRESTLING AND FACES 8 monologues). Effective speakers have been historically advantaged in ascending hierarchies.

From this communication is the emergence of both heroes (called babyfaces) and villains (heels) whose tactics resonate with humans' evolved understanding of coalitional allies and cheaters (Cosmides et al., 2005). With formidable men's heuristic expectation to ascend a wrestling hierarchy, promoters could harness the implicit understanding of the dual signal value that masculinized features present to perceivers (Geniole & McCormick, 2013). Formidable men are interpersonally gregarious, which affords them elevated group status (e.g., Brown et al., 2022d;Lukaszewski et al., 2016;Rodriguez & Lukaszewski, 2020). Nonetheless, these physical advantages calibrate men to endorse aggressive behavior that perceivers recognize through facial features that appear angry (Brown et al., 2022a;Lukaszewski, 2013). Within legitimate sport, physically large male athletes are more aggressive (Webster et al., 2021). Given the considerable acuity of perceivers toward formidable men's behavioral repertoire (e.g., Haselhuhn et al., 2013), these competing signal values could implicate high-fWHR men as capable of portraying both babyfaces and heels.

div.head: Current Study
div.p: This experiment assessed how wrestling fans perceive men's fWHR. The accuracy with which perceivers recognize men's actual striking ability and upper body strength through masculinized features led me to predict that high-fWHR men would appear more effective as brawlers and powerhouses (Zilioli et al., 2015). The concomitant stereotypes of formidable facial structures connoting less mental sophistication further led us to predict less effectiveness in being technicians or high-flyers due to the perceived complexity of such moves .
However, a competing signal value of high-fWHR men as effective grapplers led us to predict the perceived difference for technical wrestling will be smaller (Caton et al., in press).

div.head: WRESTLING AND FACES 9
div.p: This study considered further how targets could appear to work a match more effectively (i.e., "working" a match), which saw me assess perceptions of their abilities as showmen and workers. Given that perceptions of fortitude track men's fWHR and the generally affiliative nature of formidable men that draws attention from conspecifics (Brown et al., 2021;Rodriguez & Lukaszewski, 2020), I predicted that high-fWHR men will appear as better workers and showmen. Additionally, these advantages led me to predict that wrestling fans would want to push these wrestlers. Finally, the connotation of hostility in high-fWHR men led me to predict that participants would view high-fWHR men more as heels than babyfaces (Brown et al., 2022c). I report all measures, materials, and exclusions in this manuscript. Data and materials for this study are available: https://osf.io/b3fvh/?view_only=d2a228da8c9e4274bb3e177b5d4b5122 White men from the Chicago Faces Database (Ma et al., 2015). These targets originated from a subset exhibiting the highest and lowest fWHRs, with participants evaluating five from the high-fWHR category and five from the low-fWHR category . Previous research indicates that participants reliably differ in perceived strength and aggression (Brown et al., 2022a(Brown et al., , 2022b. I chose these targets from the subset based on appearing to be similar ages (i.e., early 20s) while having similar levels of attractiveness. See Figure 1 for examples.

Targets had an explicitly noted physical size between 95-100kg (i.e., 190-220lb.) to participants. This weight range is conventionally recognized among wrestling fans as a more versatile weight class for potentially using different styles (e.g., junior heavyweights), which would reduce the possibility of expectancy biases in participants for evaluating heavier or lighter targets (e.g., infrequency of so-called "super heavyweights" as high-flyers). Participants evaluated targets in random order.

Perceptions. I tasked participants with indicating the extent to which targets appeared good at five broad wrestling styles ostensibly known broadly by wrestling fans: brawler, technician, high-flyer, powerhouse, and showman. Such terminology is ubiquitous in the folk language of professional wrestling, as evidenced by their pervasiveness on fan sites (e.g., The Internet Wrestling Database). Participants viewed examples of wrestlers of each type.

Additional single-item questions assessed perceptions of targets as good at promos and working (i.e., ability to perform the match; Herzog, 1999). Another item assessed how worthy of a push the targets were (i.e., being positioned as a star within a promotion). These items operated on 7-point scales (1=Not at All; 7=Very Much). One other item assessed the booked alignment of the targets, with higher scores reflecting a greater likelihood of booking the target as a babyface WRESTLING AND FACES 11 (1= Heel; 4=Tweener; 7=Babyface). I aggregated scores for each target category into composites.

div.head: Wrestling Styles
div.p: This analysis was a 5 (Wrestling Style: Brawler vs. Technician vs. High-Flyer vs.
Powerhouse vs. Showman) × 2 (Target fWHR: High-fWHR vs. Low-fWHR) repeated ANOVA.

The complexity of this analysis led me to report only interactive effects to reduce the likelihood of Type I Errors. This analytic strategy additionally affords more conservative analyses (see Fink et al., 2019). Table 2 provides relevant descriptive statistics.

The two-way interaction emerged, F(3.41, 337.89)=246.60, p<0.001, ηp²=0.714 ( Figure 2). Simple effects tests indicated that high-fWHR targets appeared more effective as brawlers Viewed another way, two simple effects emerged for high-fWHR (ηp²=0.783) and low-fWHR targets (ηp²=0.851), Fs>86.76, ps<0.001. Pairwise comparisons for high-fWHR targets indicated that targets appeared most effective as powerhouses, followed by technicians, then powerhouses, then showmen, and finally high-flyers. All differences were significant with brawler (ps<0.001, ds>0.59). For technicians, the difference was significant for high-flyer and showman styles (ps<0.001, ds>0.30) but not for the powerhouse style (p=0.061, d=0.37). For high-flyers, the difference was significant with powerhouse and showman styles (ps<0.001, ds>0.85). The difference between the powerhouse and showman style was not significant (p=0.295, d=0.10). Low-fWHR targets appeared most effective as technicians, followed by high-WRESTLING AND FACES 12 flyers, then as showmen, then as brawlers, and finally powerhouses. All differences were significant (ps<0.001, ds>0.59), except for technician versus high-flyer (p=0.089, d=0.18).

div.head: Wrestling Presentation
div.p: The next analyses were paired-samples t-tests comparing perceptions of effectiveness in working, promos, character alignment, and interest in pushing the targets. High-fWHR targets appeared to be better workers and talkers; participants were also more willing to push them, ts>2.12, ps<0.017, ds>0.21. Low-fWHR targets appeared more likely to be babyfaces than high-fWHR targets, t(99) =8.68, p<0.001, d=0.87.

div.head: Mediation Analyses
div.p: My next step was to identify whether perceived advantages for high-fWHR men would form the basis of a subsequent push while identifying the potential mechanistic underpinnings of these inferences. I conducted a mediation analysis based on difference scores for my candidate predictors, mediators, and outcome. This analytic strategy is commonplace for within-subjects variables due to the considerable relation between variables (Trafimow, 2015). These difference scores. I subtracted the scores for low-fWHR targets from high-fWHR targets. Higher score reflected perceptions of high-fWHR targets as better at a given style or having an advantage in speaking, working, and receiving a push. Because there was no difference in perceived effectiveness as a showman, I did not consider that variable further. Table 3 provides For perceived advantages as technicians, the mediation pathway for an advantage in working was not significant, 95% CI [-0.01, 0.13]. The mediation pathway for perceived promo advantages did not include 0, but the lower confidence interval approached 0 to such a degree, that the potential indirect effect appears negligible and thus discussed no further, 95% CI [<0.01, 0.23].

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The implicit connection between fWHR and perceived competencies in professional wrestling led to high-fWHR men appearing most effective with brawling and powerhouse styles.

These perceptions align with inferences implicating formidable men as both physically strong and effective fighters (Brown et al., 2022a;Zilioli et al., 2015). These inferences are additionally the impetus behind an interest in pushing formidable men. Formidability appears capable of shaping evaluations of simulated combat (Sugiyama et al., 2021).

Low-fWHR men appeared advantaged as technicians and high-flyers. High-fWHR men could appear incapable of mental complexity (Deska et al., 2017). This inference could reflect that high-fWHR men are physically larger, thus disadvantaging men from performing aerial WRESTLING AND FACES 14 moves (e.g., moonsaults). Perceptions of technical prowess was magnitudinally smaller, suggesting a more salient competition between signal values of facial structures.

Ascriptions of high-fWHR men as mentally unsophisticated could interfere with an awareness of their advantages in grappling (Caton et al., in press). The effectiveness of high-fWHR men as technicians was tied closely to perceptions of them as powerhouses, whereas a similar connection emerged for low-fWHR men appearing as effective technicians and highflyers. For high-fWHR men, their inferred strength could implicate them as effective with technical throws (e.g., Taz), whereas low-fWHR could be seen as more proficient with granularity in joint locks (e.g., Zack Sabre, Jr.). Future research could consider the specificity behind these types of maneuvers, which could be informed by previous research assessing specific combat roles among coalition members (e.g., Brown et al., 2022a).

Interestingly, high-fWHR men appeared more effective as heels than faces. This inference could reflect the fact that masculinized facial structures appear especially aggressive to perceivers (Geniole & McCormick, 2013), with this signal value superseding awareness of the coalitional benefits afforded by formidability. Heel wrestlers' status as the villain would position them to benefit from appearing aggressive and thus capable of appearing as exploitative to perceivers (Cosmides et al., 2005;Sell et al., 2009). Nonetheless, the signal value of aggressive tendencies appears most salient in facial structures tied to emotional displays (Brown et al., 2022b). Future research would benefit from identifying how different connotations of formidability inform specific perceptions of a professional wrestler's alignment.

div.head: Limitations and Future Directions
div.p: Although such findings remain sensible in light of affordance management theories of social perception, several limitations emerged that necessitate future research. First, despite the WRESTLING AND FACES 15 large kernel of truth in formidability inferences (e.g., Haselhuhn et al., 2013;Zilioli et al., 2015), our findings could be driven more readily by stereotypes informed more readily by expectations of high-fWHR men as stronger and more aggressive (Durkee & Ayers, 2021). Future research would benefit from identifying the facial morphology of actual professional wrestlers while similarly assessing the extent to which these men enjoyed tangible success in the industry by virtue of appearing formidable (Caton et al., in press). Researchers could identify the facial landmarks predictive of success with relevant metrics indicative of success in professional wrestling (e.g., number of main event matches).

Future work could address how racial stereotypes inform inferences. Perceptions of formidability are larger for Black men (Brown et al., 2022c;Wilson et al., 2017). Black and White wrestlers' capabilities could appear differently to perceivers based on concomitant stereotyes. Additionally, the historic employment of Asian wrestlers to adopt underhanded foreign heel characters in U.S. (e.g., Yoshihiro Tajiri using the "Asian mist") could undermine an interest in booking Asian men as top stars for not appearing sufficiently masculine by American standards (Goh & Trofimchuk, 2022;Johnson et al., 2012). Nonetheless, Japanese wrestling promotions present many Asian wrestlers as rugged characters (e.g., Kenta Kobashi, Tomohiro Ishii), suggesting these stereotypes are Western-specific. Future research could identify the sociocultural interplay in these inferences.

My explicit indication of the targets' general weight could invite future research to identify boundary conditions. Larger wrestlers could appear more unilaterally effective at certain strategies beyond their facial appearance . Conversely, the signal value of high-fWHR could implicate smaller wrestlers as more effective as a powerhouse, given that fWHR connotes actual formidability across weight classes (Zilioli et al., 2015).

It should be further noted that these effects are specific to male wrestlers. Given previous research indicating less automaticity in identifying formidability through female faces (Sell et al., 2009) and a lack of association between fWHR and women's fighting ability (Palmer-Hague et al., 2018), future research could consider the morphological features most predictive of women's success in professional wrestling. Although body mass is highly diagnostic of women's fighting ability, considerable heterogeneity exists among female professional wrestlers. Female wrestlers vary in their presentation considerably while ultimately creating well-received and realistic performances from physically attractive and smaller women (e.g., Lita, Becky Lynch, Manami Toyota). The heterogeneity could be due to the relative irrelevance for upper body strength and physical conflict in women's sexual selection and the fact that such features are regarded as unattractive in women (Puts, 2010;Sell et al., 2012; for a discussion, see Griskevicius et al., 2009). The selection pressures that shaped women's lower body composition (e.g., wider hips) could provide relevant information for many inferences (Puts, 2016). That is, the importance of women's lower extremities in mate preferences that facilitated wider hips and gluteofemoral deposits could generate a heuristic of women's fighting ability, namely based in lower centers of gravity (Brooks et al., 2015;Heid et al., 2010).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: These data suggest that the presentation of professional wrestling is informed by ancestral logic to ensure group survival. High-fWHR men appear most effective at portraying a legitimate contest in various domains. Such perceptions create the basis for a cultural evolution that bestows status to formidability in the form of a push into the main event.

figure.figDesc: professional wrestling fans from various social media outlets (e.g., Reddit, Twitter; 88 men, 10 women, 2 undisclosed; MAge=34.71, SD=8.41; 69% White). Online communities are comprised of individuals with extensive knowledge on professional wrestling and its inner workings (e.g., backstage news) across different countries (e.g., United States, Japan). That is, these participants were aware of the scripted nature of professional wrestling.This sample reported being especially knowledgeable on the topic (1=Not at All Knowledgeable; 10=Very Knowledgeable; M=8.39, SD=1.71), although knowledge did not moderate findings. A sensitivity analysis indicated that I was adequately powered for small effects(Cohen's d=0.29,. No data were excluded from final analyses.Materials and ProcedureSocial Targets. Participants were tasked with serving as a hypothetical wrestling booker WRESTLING AND FACES 10 who had to evaluate a series of young wrestlers who recently completed training. Targets were 10

ηp²=0.801) and powerhouses than low-fWHR targets (ηp²=0.661), Fs>193.09, ps<0.001. Low-fWHR targets appeared more effective as high-flyers (ηp²=0.661) and technicians (ηp²=0.098), Fs>10.73, ps<0.002. No difference emerged for high-fWHR and low-fWHR targets as showmen, F(1, 99)=2.28, p=0.134, ηp²=0.022l.

relevant bivariate correlations. The perceived advantage of high-fWHR men as effective brawlers was associated with perceptions of them being better at promos, but not working. Perceptions of an advantage for high-fWHR men as technicians were associated with perceptions of both their abilities with working and promos. No significant associations emerged for high-flyers or powerhouses toward the candidate mediators. Perceptions of high-fWHR men as better brawlers, technicians, and powerhouses were associated with an interest in pushing high-fWHR men. Perceptions of high-fWHR men as better with working (r=0.36, p<0.001) and promos (r=0.60, p<0.001) were associated with greater interest in pushing them. 2 My final step was to conduct two mediation analyses based on significant correlations between the candidate mediators, predictors, and outcome. I considered perceived advantages of high-fWHR men as brawlers and technicians as predictors. Promo ability was the candidate mediator for brawlers and both candidate mediators were in the model for technicians. I used Model 4 of PROCESS with 10000 bootstraps(Hayes, 2013). For perceived advantages as brawlers, the indirect effect through perceived advantages in promos was, 95% CI [0.06, 0.29].

The examples were the wrestlers presented to participants in the instructions for each style. Means (and standard deviations) for perceived ability of high-fWHR and low-fWHR targets across different types of wrestling characters, promos, working, worthiness of a push, and alignment. Note. High scores reflect appearing more like a babyface. Bivariate correlations for difference scores of perceived high-fWHR advantage for given wrestling styles with candidate mediators (i.e., ability as a worker and promo ability) and an interest in pushing high-fWHR targets. Note. Positive associations reflect an advantage for high-fWHR targets in a given domain.
